on in addition to the global globally

Shopify itself has been growing rapidly

is what we call our GMV for the Black

weekends and we see that this number has

which means that the infrastructure has

observability
platform which we call observe uh the

um the reason why we do this is so that
we can actually
uh connect a lot of Shopify specific dom
uh domain specific information a lot of

they're quite significant and um these
were the numbers at peak black Friday
last year and they're already reality
today
um due to the growth of the
platform so before we talk about
integrating serverless into this I just
want to give a give a brief overview of
how applications get deployed to
production
uh for a while now um Shopify has been
kind of running exclusively on
Kubernetes uh we're hosted in Google
Cloud and the the key difference here is
that
um engineers don't necessarily get to
write Kubernetes manifests so they write
something that's called a runtime
manifest and then the production
platform takes that runtime manifest
generates Kubernetes manifests and
applies them to Kubernetes and manages
all of the life cycle of the application
and during this process we kind of wire
up all of the observability
um essentially
um engineers only need to worry about
instrumentation and then we make sure
that those instrumentation signals get
collected in whatever way we decide is
appropriate um that's different
obviously for traces metrics and logs
and profiles as well uh but where those
signals need to be sent is not the
concern of the application
engineer um and so about a year ago um
Shopify started looking into moving
certain workloads to serverless so we're
not talking about fully replacing
Kubernetes but rather extending the
capabilities of the platform with um
serverless as
well our main motivation was that we had
a lot of uh hackathon projects and
experimental projects that would just
get forgotten and would run somewhere on
the side no one would uh even know that
they're running and this obviously costs
money um so with serverless we had the
ability to automatically scale these um
these workloads to zero replicas and
zero zero dollars and then the flip side
of that is that if we had to serve
production traffic um serverless
obviously can scale up to to kind of u
more or less you know in theory an
arbitrary load um so we didn't we we
were ready to go um if we really needed
to serve production
traffic so for serless we also have a
manifest uh which engineers provide uh
in this particular case uh this from
this manifest we would generate the GCP
project a cloud run environment um then
we would set up a domain name for the
application um this application would
get its own database its own Kafka
consumer uh and uh it just would be
ready to go so this kind of uh
deployment model is quite simple and
elegant in the sense that it provides a
self-contained
application but in our case it also
comes with a wide set of challenges so
to begin with uh new projects uh or
rather every service project runs
basically in the Google proprietary
network uh to which we don't necessarily
have direct access so things like
scraping metrics becomes very difficult
um and also pushing metrics from the
application to the observability service
um is also becomes non-trivial because
now we have to go over the public
internet for
example uh we also don't have access to
the underlying nodes so a lot of the
aggregation patterns that we use uh to
aggregate logs metrics and so forth are
simply not feasible in this environment
and finally application instances can be
just evicted and terminated at any point
in time so whatever aggregation we do in
the application has to be done very
carefully and uh so that we don't
necessarily lose data
so with that in mind um I'll now hand it
off to Pedro to kind of walk you through
the solution and architecture that we
put in place for instrumenting
serverless applications
all right so as you saw uh we were left
with in a point where we had to tackle

uh extension of the production platform
basically in three categories um
instrumentation and so how we managed to

of stats D at Shopify we are rubbish
shop and by default we use um stats D as
other as a default
instrumentation stats D on a on on one
hand can be very very good very simple
uh it's a textbased protocol we usually
it's usually very light on resources for

be quite verbose as we can see here for
a single application where we're sending
this stat sample if the application is
receiving,000 requests per second it
will be producing about 6.5 megabytes of
only stats data so it's very very
important to have aggregation on the
client
side and so we wanted to allow existing
Ruby apps to keep sending data the way
that they were used to which is stat but
also push the new services uh written in
other languages uh to use open
telemetry and so the open telemetry
allowed allowed us to do that but with
some limitations because at the moment
when we started did this work at version
0.84 of the open telemetry uh collector
contrib it didn't have support for the

had to let to leverage this um hotel

where we fork for forked the um stats

have actually been incorpored into the
um upstream version
so once we had decided that uh that we

to use the hotel collector
um we wanted to move in that direction
but we don't didn't know how um and that
was when we talked with Google or our
cloud provider and we opt in for a new

and this would allow us to basically run
um the hotel collector as a side card to

traffic uh on the loop back as UDP but
also send OTLP
um also via the loop back interface and
then ship outside of the project uh
through the public internet OTP using
protobuff u plus compression which is
much more efficient than sending uh all
of these stats these
samples so we landed on this
architecture at the end where we have um
applications running on cloud run here
they are sending metrics to the sidecar
as I said either via stats or
OTLP then the the work of the collector
here is to batch the metrics together
and also do some aggregation and then
send this batched metrics through a

projects so they have to send um the the
information via the public

uh and this metric router will forward

better much
uh simpler step so they we send also

trace storage

will lose the
information yeah so once we deployed

saw that some clients were losing
metrics here then here and there and in
serverless uh the main thing is that
really everything is preemptable and you
may end up losing data if you don't
configure um your observability
workloads properly so we had to reduce a
lot the flushing interval of the hotel
collector also uh in cloud run you just
get 10 seconds of grace period and it's
not configurable so if you don't flush
um when the container receives a s term
if you don't flush in 10 seconds you
will lose everything that is in in
transit in memory
uh and also we had to set up really good
ordering of the containers to make sure
that the application didn't go up and

collector was ready to receive metrics
and traces
uh some of the wins that we had and

this was really good and having this all
